The Government of Cambodia is committed to sustaining high rates of 
economic  growth  and  to  meeting  the  Millennium  Development  Goal 
targets. Cambodia’s growth has been unevenly concentrated in urban 
areas; a key thrust of the National Strategic Development Plan (NSDP) 
2006–2010  is  to  reduce  rural  poverty,  particularly  through  policy  and 
financial support to the agriculture sector. Agriculture employs 70% of 
the rural population and accounts for about one-third of gross domestic 
product  (GDP).  Yet  the  public  financial  management  (PFM)  system 
that  manages  and  delivers  the  resources  for  rural  development  is 
constrained in a number of areas. Most critically, government capacity 
is  limited  in  the  area  of  PFM,  where  a  scarcity  of  qualified  and 
competent  finance  specialists  and  line  managers  severely  affect  the 
quality and effectiveness of the budget process. 
 
The  Public  Financial  Management  Reform  Program  (PFMRP)  was 
launched in December 2004 by the Ministry of Economy and Finance 
(MEF)  to  address  weaknesses  in  the  PFM  system.  PFMRP  aims  to 
establish  a  strong  PFM  system  to  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the 
NSDP.  It  has  been  designed  as  a  long-term  rolling  program,  building 
on  a  series  of  platforms.  The  four  platforms  specify  a  package  of 
reform  activities,  including  complementary  institutional,  capacity  and 
incentive reforms that, when completed, will provide a comprehensive 
PFM system for Cambodia. Platform 1 has already been implemented. 
Its objective was to make the budget more credible as an instrument of 
strategic  management  of  public  resources  and  to  hold  budget 
managers accountable for efficient use of these resources. 
 
Of  particular  concern  for  rural  development,  is  the  fact  that  the  line 
ministries which support rural development in Cambodia are currently

The Macroeconomic Context 
 
2. 
Sustained High Economic Growth. Cambodia is at a crossroads as it transits from the 
legacy  of  its  conflict-ridden  past  and  attempts  to  build  institutions  of  democratic  governance. 
Strengthening  institutions  in  a  range  of  areas  and  economic  policies  is  important  not  only  for 
reducing the risk of future conflict, but also for attracting foreign investments to support broad-
based economic recovery. Cambodia has recorded double-digit economic growth over the last 4 
years,  averaging  11%  annually  (Table  1  overleaf).  This  growth  has  been  driven  primarily  by 
industry  (garments  and  construction  in  particular).  Economic  growth  reached  10.2%  in  2007, 
with  the  services  sector  growing  faster  than  the  industrial  sector.  Up  to  mid-2007,  economic 
growth  occurred  in  an  environment  of  modest  inflation,  with  rates  fluctuating  between  4%  and 
6%  between  2005  and  2007.  Exports—mainly  garments—grew  by  11%  in  2007  while  imports 
expanded by 14%, reflecting increased demand for investment goods. Overall, the trade deficit 
was 15.5% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2007 and 15.4% for the first 7 months of 2008. 
With tourism reaching new heights, the current account deficit was 8.1% of GDP for the first 7 
months  of  2008  and  rapid  capital  inflows  took  the  balance  of  payments  to  a  surplus  of  4%  of 
GDP in 2007. 
 
3. 
Fiscal  Policy  Has  Generally  Been  Prudent.  Given  its  importance  to  macroeconomic 
management,  fiscal  policy  has  been  the  key  to  the  pro-growth  investment  environment  in 
Cambodia.  The 2007 budget results did not vary substantially from past budgets, as revenue 
collections  were  above  target  and  expenditures  were  contained  close  to  target  levels.  The 
budget’s  primary  balance  showed  a  healthy  surplus,  while  the  overall  deficit,  incorporating 
investment outlays, amounted to a deficit of only about 0.4% of GDP for the first 7 months of 
2008, continuing the trend over the last few years. However, the Government budget continued 
to  be  contractionary,  while  Government  deposits  in  the  banking  system  have  continued  to 
increase.  While  the  macroeconomic  variables  of  economic  growth  and  balance  of  payments 
were still clearly robust in 2007, there is cause for concern in 2008 and beyond unless inflation 
is brought under control. 

 

4. 
Challenges  to  Sustaining  Economic  growth  in  2008  and  2009.  Recent    global 
economic  problems  have  negatively  affected  demand  for  Cambodian  exports.  The  sharp 
slowdown in the US economy, for example, is affecting US demand for garment exports from 
Cambodia, which fell by 1% in the first quarter of 2008 compared to the same period of 2007. 
The unexpected recent surge in international food and energy prices has translated to double-
digit  rates  of  inflation  in  2008;  this  in  turn  is  slowing  household  consumption  and  economic 
growth. Recent increases in oil prices may cut the economic growth rate by as much as three 
percentage points in 2008 (to about 6.5%), as production costs in Cambodia tend to have high 
fuel components. ADB forecasts that Cambodia’s economic growth may slow by as much as 3

percentage points in 2008, mostly because of increased fuel costs. This forecast is consistent 
with the Government’s own forecasts, which put economic growth in the range of 6–8% in 2008. 
High  inflation  will  have  a  negative  impact  on  poverty  incidence  in  urban  centers,  and  if  it 
persists may also affect Cambodia’s Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a poverty 
rate of 28% by 2010.

Sector Performance 
 
8. 
Poverty in Cambodia is Primarily a Rural Phenomenon. Economic growth has been 
the  main  driver  of  social  and  economic  development  in  Cambodia.  The  national  poverty  rate 

 

  

 

5 

declined  from  47%  in  1994  to  34%  in  2004.  While  the  benefits  of  growth  have  been  widely 
spread  across  Cambodia,  the  rural  poverty  rate  has  not  declined  as  expected,  and  was 
estimated at 39% in 2004. With 80% of the population residing outside the main urban centers, 
this translates to more than 4 million persons living below the poverty line in rural areas. Rural 
poverty in Cambodia has other dimensions besides low incomes. The poor have limited access 
to  basic  goods  and  services  such  as  clean  water,  education,  and  health  services.  These  are 
problems  that  Cambodia  needs  to  overcome  to  achieve  several  of  its  key  MDGs  (Table  1). 
Cambodia’s  MDG  target  for  poverty  is  24%  of  the  population  by  2015.  To  achieve  this  target 
will  require  average  economic  growth  of  7.5%  per  annum  from  2008  to  2015,  inflation  in  the 
range of 3%, and no change in the distribution of income between urban and rural families. If 
inequality  between  rural  and  urban  areas  increases,  higher  growth  may  be  necessary  to 
achieve  this  target. 5  Thus,  increasing  the  efficiency  of  public  resources  targeted  for  rural 
development  and  increasing  private  sector-led  economic  opportunities  in  rural  areas  will  be 
crucially important to accomplishing Cambodia’s MDG for poverty reduction. 
 

9. 
Income  Inequality  (Figures  2  and  3).  Cambodia’s  average  living  standards  as 
measured by consumption of goods and services per capita per day, increased by 32% in real 
terms between 1994 and 2004 (Figure 2). However, the increase in rural living standards was 
slower than in Phnom Penh and other major urban centers. Consequently, inequality measured 
by  the  Gini  coefficient  increased  from  0.35  in  1994  to  0.4  in  2004.  The  increase  in  inequality 
has primarily been caused by rapid urban growth, much of which occurred between 1994 and 
1997. Some widening of inequality is expected as a country develops, since growth tends to be 
urban-driven.  Some  of  the  gap  also  arose  because  of  unequal  access  to  public  services  and 
resources, but this  gap has narrowed since 1997. Various measures of school enrollment and 
mortality  rates  in  rural  areas  have  fallen  over  time.  The  disparity  in  access  to  infrastructure 
(roads), amenities (clean water and electricity), and basic services (schooling, healthcare) also 
narrowed between 1997 and 2004, as did gender gaps in literacy and schooling.

The Government has prioritized the education and health sectors for larger shares of the 
national  Government  budget.  This  will  benefit  rural  schools  and  health  clinics.  The 
Government’s  broad  policy  on  allocation  of  expenditures  to  achieve  growth  and  development 
was to increase and then stabilize social-sector spending at current levels relative to GDP. To 
date the Government has prioritized social-sector spending over providing significant increases 
in expenditure on economic sectors (agriculture and infrastructure). From Figure 4 (overleaf) it 
can  be  seen  that  expenditures  on  core  Government  activities  decreased  from  62%  to  45%  of 
the  executed  state  budget  between  1995  and  2007.  This  may  have  resulted  partially  from 
increased  expenditures  on  health  (from  4.6%  to  10.51%)  and  on  education  (from  9.1%  to 
14.81%)  over  the  same  period.  Expenditures  on  economic  services,  on  the  other  hand, 
increased from 10.8% of executed expenditures in 1995 to 16.9% in 2001, before declining to 
7.3%  in  2007.  However,  given  that  rural  poverty  persists,  the  Government  is  now  looking  to 
redress the balance between social- and economic-sector spending. Agriculture in particular will 
benefit from an increased share of Government investment from 2009. 
 

 

  

 

7 

A key thrust of the NSDP 2006–2010 is to encourage growth in rural areas, in particular 
13. 
in the agriculture sector. Agriculture, which employs 70% of the rural population and accounts 
for  about  one-third  of  GDP,  remains  vulnerable  to  external  shocks  and  unfavorable  weather 
conditions.  Productivity  in  the  agriculture  sector  is  also  low.  The  NSDP  aims  to  reduce  the 
vulnerability of the agriculture sector and increase agricultural productivity through land reforms 
and expansion of rural credit, among other measures. Improving rural infrastructure will also be 
critical to reducing rural poverty and income inequality between rural and urban areas. Improved 
rural  infrastructure  will  increase  rural  dwellers'  access  to  services  and  markets  for  goods  and 
services. However, rural development ministries  will require increased resources to implement 
these reforms.  
 
14. 
The challenge for Cambodia will be to sustain economic growth in the range of 7–9% per 
annum, accelerate the creation of productive jobs, and reduce poverty. This will be no easy task 
with  half  the  population  under  20  years  of  age  and  more  than  85%  of  employment  in  the 
informal sector (mainly subsistence agriculture), not to mention the relatively high rural poverty 
rate  of  around  39%.  The  Government  recognizes  that  the  key  to  sustaining  high  economic 
growth and reducing poverty is to diversify sources of economic growth from its current narrow 
base  in  construction,  garments,  and  tourism,  which  accounts  for  42% of  non-agriculture  GDP. 
Sustaining  high  economic  growth  over  the  long  term  will  require  economic  diversification  and 
closer  links  between  agriculture  and  service  sectors.  Promoting  economic  diversification  will 
require  further  reforms  at  several  levels  of  the  economy,  including:  (i)  reforms  in  agriculture, 
investment climate, and trade policy to improve competitiveness at all levels of the supply chain, 
from  agriculture  to  the  customs  border  transit  points;  (ii)  increases  in  public  capital  spending, 
especially  in  rural  areas,  in  agriculture,  and  in  the  energy  sector  (rural  electrification);  and  (iii) 
public  expenditure  management  reforms  to  align  strategic  objectives  with  budget  outputs  and 
the medium-term expenditure framework; and to improve budget execution, reporting, efficiency 
and  transparency.  The  Government’s  economic  strategies,  such  as  those  articulated  in  its 
Diagnostic  Trade  Integrated  Strategy,  underline  the  critical  importance  of  agriculture  and  rural 
development as the key to economic diversification.  
 
15. 
Donor-financed  capital  allocations  for  the  rural  sector  are  also  expected  to  scale  up 
resources in the near term, in line with the Government's priority to support the development of 
productive  sectors  and  further  reduce  rural  poverty  rates.  Rolling  out  PFM  reforms  to  rural 
development agencies will be crucial to ensuring that priority spending is carried out efficiently 
and  transparently,  and  will  ultimately  lead  to  economic  diversification  and  reduced poverty.  Of 
particular concern for rural development is the fact that the three line ministries—MAFF, MRD, 
and  MOWRAM—are  not  sufficiently  resourced.  Low  levels  of  funding  and  unskilled  human 
resources  further  exacerbates  public  expenditure  inefficiencies  and  contributes  directly  to  low 
levels of service delivery in rural areas, which subsequently reduces economic opportunities for 
the rural poor.

18. 
Notwithstanding the Government’s commitment, implementation of the NSDP objectives 
to support rural development is constrained by (i) Cambodia’s weak PFM system, (ii) capacity 
and resource constraints in the MEF, which hinder rollout of the full PFMRP to line ministries, 
including the rural development ministries, (iii) limited human resource capacity in line ministries 
to manage and deliver services, (iv) scarcity of resources available to implement policy priorities, 
and (iv) governance challenges that undermine the effectiveness of the budget as an instrument 
to  affect  rural  poverty.  The  rollout  of  ongoing  PFM  reforms  to  the  three  rural  development 
ministries is, therefore, critical to NSDP objectives. In the three rural development  ministries it 
will be important to build commensurate capacity by rolling out the training program and other 
measures  designed  under  the  PFMRP  on  a  priority  basis.  As  such,  involvement  of  rural 
development  ministries  and  a  sense  of  ownership  of  the  PFMRP  by  these  ministries  is  a 
prerequisite for the realization of an effective system-wide PFM structure in Cambodia—that is, 
a  PFM  system  that  can  deliver  efficient  public  sector-funded  outcomes.  In  addition  to  the 
following discussion, Appendix 5 analyses in detail the underlying issues.

In an effort to establish an effective and efficient PFM system, the Government instituted 
20. 
the multi-stage PFMRP to reform Cambodia’s PFM system, in December 2004. With a 10-year 
planning  and  implementation  horizon,  the  PFMRP  is  being  supported  through  a  sector-wide 
approach with financing from a number of development partners, primarily through a multi-donor 
trust  fund.7 However,  other  donors,  such  as  ADB,  will  be  supporting  the  sector-wide  approach 
through  a  proposed  budget  support  grant  to  Cambodia  to  strengthen  rural  PFM  systems.  The 
first  stage  of  the  PFMRP,  platform  1,  was  completed  in  2007.  Platform  1  was  rolled  out  to 
improve  budget  credibility  and  the  day-to-day  management  of  public  resources  by  delivering 
reliable  and  predictable  resources  to  individual  managers.  Activities  undertaken  included 
improving budget formulation and execution; improving sustainability of the budget; developing 
a  revenue  strategy;  improving  the  macroeconomic  framework;    developing  debt-management 
tools and streamlining the ability of budget entities to spend in line with their budget approvals; 
streamlining  the  resource  commitment  and  payment  process,  including  outsourcing  of  MEF 
financial  controllers  to  selected  line  ministries;  reforming  the  procurement  processes  of  line 
ministries; increasing use of the banking system and reducing the use of cash for Government 
transactions; commencing the consolidation of Government bank accounts into a treasury single 
account; and eliminating arrears.  

 

21. 
For  the  second  stage  of  the  program,  the  Government,  with  assistance  from 
development  partners,  has  prepared  'platform  2'  for  implementation  between  late  2008  and 
2011.  The  goal  of  platform  2  is  to  improve  financial  management  accountability  so  that  civil 
servants at all levels feel responsible for how they manage and control public finances. Building 
internal  audit  capacity  has  been  identified  as  a  key  objective  of  the  PFMRP  toward  achieving 
this  goal.  An  effective  internal  audit  function  will  ensure  that  (i)  adequate  control  systems  are 
established so that assets are safeguarded; (ii) financial reports are reliable; (iii) laws, policies, 
and  procedures  are  complied  with;  (iv)  resources  are  used  efficiently;  (v)  and  the  overall 
objectives  of  the  spending  entity  are  achieved.  Internal  audit  units  face  the  challenge  of 
ensuring that capacity is built so that they can deliver a professional service.

Therefore,  in  the  context  of  the  fiscal  and  budget  implications  of  debt  sustainability

system as integral to PFMRP reforms and ensuring sustainable priority spending over the long

treasury bills) and no external commercial borrowing. The debt-to-GDP ratio declined from 31%

anticipates  that,  over  the  longer  term,  a  more  complicated  debt  structure  will  evolve  as  the 
economy develops and begins to raise finances from other sources beyond official development 
assistance (ODA) Going forward, strengthening capacity at the debt management office (DMO) 
will  require  a  functioning  middle  office,  capacity  building  of  staff  in  producing  a  debt-
management  strategy  and  starting  regular  debt  reporting,  and  drafting  decrees  in  the  area  of

public debt management.

30. 
Ownership  and  capacity  building  are  the  themes  that  have  underpinned  ADB 
governance-reform assistance and public expenditure management assistance over the years. 
They are the same themes that will inform the design of the proposed Program. In Cambodia’s 
institutional  and  political  reform  context,  donor  coordination  is  necessary  for  successful 
implementation.  An  important  lesson  learned  from  previous  PFM  interventions  in  Cambodia  is 
that  introducing  complex  PFM  reforms  in  a  capacity-constrained  environment  such  as 
Cambodia  requires  a  step-by-step  approach  to  reform.  Another  lesson  is  that  introducing  the 
broader  institutional  and  organizational  changes  needed  for  certain  technical  PFM  reforms  to 
work  requires  high-level  Government  commitment  and  engagement  with  the  reform  program. 
The stage-by-stage approach being used for the PFM reform program allows PFM changes to 
be introduced gradually, while complementary capacity and skills development will feature as a 
key  component  of  the  final  PFM  reform  program.  The  key  lesson  is  that  it  is  necessary  to 
engage  for  a  longer  period  of  time  and  to  respond  flexibly  to  changes  in  priorities  during 
implementation. Resident PFM consultants or peripatetic advisers that are actively advising or 
providing hands-on assistance will help ensure that priority reforms are implemented.

Lessons from two ADB studies (by the Operations Evaluation Department) also suggest 
that (i) policy reforms involving passage of legislation need sufficient time to allow for consensus 
building  and  explanation  to  stakeholders,  so  delays  in  the  achievement  of  some  expected 
outcomes are likely; (ii) technical assistance for capacity development to institutionalized skills 
transfer; (iii) it is necessary to pursue governance issues not only at the project/program level, 
but also at the level of donors’ collective policy dialogue to ensure Government commitment to 
addressing widespread corruption; (iv) support for capacity development should focus not only 
on institutionalizing skills transfer, with a clear exit strategy, but also on improving organizational 
management  and  budgeting  systems;  and  (v)  the  existing  deterrence  factor  in  terms  of  low 
public salary structure tends to deter some expected outcomes by reducing the retention and/or 
utilization  of  trained  staff.22 These  studies  also  suggest  that  it  takes  time  to  fully  integrate  the 
medium-term expenditure framework into the annual budget cycles.

The  PFMRDP  has  several  distinctive  features.  First,  it  strengthens  ADB’s  partnership

practices  to  support  effective  delivery  of  services.  The  program  will  likewise  foster  greater

Economic and Financial Benefits. ADB estimates the main direct economic benefit in 
the near term will be the cost saving for the Government in terms of procuring consultants and 
providing  materials and equipment, including IT database systems and computers—hardware 
and  software.  Government  contracts  face  significantly  higher  than  market  prices  as  supplies 
build into the contract price the cost of delayed payment, time costs in terms of efforts made in 
dealing  with  cumbersome  processes  and  procedures  and  some  level  of  uncertainty  over 
possible forfeiture of payment (a risk payment). The benefit quantified to the Government of the 
ADB  project  is  therefore  between  $615,000  and  $820,000  for  2009. 35 Procurement  of  all  the 
inputs  for  the  project  will  take  place  in  2009;  benefits  to  the  Government  are  in  the  form  of  a 
one-off savings.

85. 
Higher Economic and Poverty Impacts. The program is expected to have substantial 
positive economic impacts. Strong PFM systems contribute to macroeconomic stability through 
improved  management  of  fiscal  expenditures  to  reduce  public  deficits  and  uncontrolled 
increases  in  the  money  supply.  Strengthening  the  PFM  system  for  rural  development  will 
contribute  to  better  planning,  management,  and  usage  of  budget  resources,  which  will  have  a 
positive  impact  on  the  rural  sector  and  employment  generation.  This  in  turn  will  ensure  a 
broadening of the tax base and will therefore contribute directly to increasing the fiscal space of 
the Government. In line with the better fiscal management, resources for sector investment will 
increase; the Program will therefore enhance the increased fiscal space for increased allocation 
for  social  sector  spending,  especially  in  rural  development  sectors,  including  agriculture,  rural 
water supply, sanitation, irrigation, and rural roads. 
 
C. 
 
Political  Risks.  Political  governance  is  a  key  risk  to  the  sustainability  of  PFM  reform. 
86. 
However, given the strong commitment at the highest level of political leadership and the broad 
consensus  on  the  direction  of  reforms  among  the  major  political  leaders,  the  risk  that  the 
trajectory and momentum of reform will be reversed is low.  
 
87. 
Institutional  Risks.  The  comprehensive  nature  of  the  program  will  place  significant 
demands  on  the  Government’s  weak  institutions.  In  PFMRP  stage  2,  the  envisaged  capacity 
development  plan  is  comprehensive  and  includes  technical,  organizational  development,  and 
motivational and change management issues.  
 
88. 
Implementation Risks. The PFMRDP may be undermined by continued and excessive 
centralization in decision making without adequate financial resources. Measures to strengthen 
technical  capacity  within  the  scope  of  the  PFMRDP  and  through  ADB  sector  investments 
include  establishment  of  a  subworking  group  proposed  under  PFMRDP,  which  will  ensure 
appropriate  coordination  arrangements  between  MEF  and  rural  development  ministries.  Close 
performance monitoring will help reduce implementation delays.  
 
91.

the  drying  up  there  of  liquidity  in  the  commercial  paper  and  related  money  and  interbank

Management  Reform  Program  (PFMRP)  platforms  have  been  designed  to  impact  two  key 
visions of the Government. First, the Government has recognized that a strong PFM system is 
vital  to  achieving  the  objectives  identified  in  the  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (NPRS). 
Second, the PFMRP will help Cambodia achieve international best practice in PFM, as defined

place  (diagram  at  page  59).  The  design  and  implementation  of  the  platform  approach  is

platforms. They aim to achieve the following objectives between 2005 and 2015: Platform 1 will 
introduce a credible budget delivering predictable resources; platform 2 will ensure an improved 
internal  control  environment  that  holds  managers  to  account;  platform  3  will  improve  the  link 
between  policy  priorities  and  budget  planning;  and  finally,  platform  4  will  ensure  integration  of 
accountability and review processes for both financial and performance management. To date, 
only platform 1 has been rolled out (between 2005 and 2008). Platform 2 will be rolled out from 
2009 to 2011.

3. 

Audit Law and Assisting NAA in Drafting of Audit Subdecrees 

 
29. 
All  of  the  essential  features  of  a  sound  and  independent  law  are  reflected  in  the  2000 
Audit Law that established the NAA. The law requires the auditor general to report directly to the 
national assembly and senate; the appointment of the auditor general requires a 51% majority 
of the national assembly; the auditor general has the authority to determine the salaries of NAA 
audit  staff;  the  law  extends  the  powers  of  the  auditor  general  to  conduct  audits  of  not  only  all 
Government  agencies,  provinces,  ministries,  state  enterprises,  and  public  authorities  but  also 
private enterprises and NGO’s that receive tax concessions from the Government, suppliers of 
goods and services to the Government under contracts and expenditures on loan projects; the 
rank of the auditor general is equivalent to that of a senior minister; NAA has its own separate 
financial budget; NAA is empowered to conduct financial, performance, and compliance audits; 
the appointments of the auditor general and deputy auditor generals are restricted to two terms 
of 5 years each; reports issued by the auditor general are deemed to be public documents. 
 
30. 
However,  there  are  areas  where  audit  law  can  be  improved  and  strengthened.  These 
relate to strengthening the independence of NAA, and establishing interfaces between the NAA 
and  other  Government  agencies  that  form  a  link  in  the  chain  of  accountability.  A  new  audit 
subdecree  will  be  required  to  clarify  NAA’s  mandate  to  address  these  shortcomings.  ADB  will 
assist  in  the  drafting  of  the  implementing  subdecrees  under  the  audit  law  of  2000.  The 
subdecree will need to look into the following: deadlines for preparation and submission of the 
audited  financial  statements  and  budget  settlement  accounts  to  the  national  assembly;  NAA’s 
role  in  the  context  of  ongoing  reforms  in  financial  management  decentralization  and 
deconcentration;  the  relationship  between  the  NAA  and  the  Commission  of  Finance,  Banking

standards, (ii) creating a solid internal control framework, (iii) working with internal auditors, and (iv)

submits copies of all internal audit reports to the NAA. An internal audit subdecree was issued

majority  of  ADB-  and  World  Bank-funded  projects.  Poor  project  preparation;  insufficient

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
 
Cambodia’s  high  income  poverty  and  non-inclusive  growth  makes  it  one  of  the  poorest  countries  of  the  world,  resulting  in 
inequalities  that  are  deep-seated  and  most  pronounced  in  the  urban–rural  divide.  The  upside  is  that  according  to  the  2004 
National Socio-Economic Survey and a number of specially commissioned studies, there has been a steady decline in poverty 
in Cambodia since the end of the civil war. The percentage of Cambodians living below the poverty line fell from an estimated 
47% in 1994 to about 35% in 2004 (source: Asian Development Bank, 2007, Country Strategy and Program Midterm Review, 
Cambodia 2005–2009).a However, over the same period Cambodia has witnessed a sharp rise in income inequality, and an 
increasing gap between the rich and the poor. Despite a marked decline in the poverty level during the period 1994–2004, a 
World  Bank  poverty  assessment  in  2006  (Cambodia:  Halving  Poverty  by  2015)b  highlighted  the  growing  incidence  of  rural 
poverty. The rise in consumption inequality has been attributed to the uneven spread of economic growth across Cambodia, 
according  to  the  World  Bank  report  Sharing  Growth:  Equity  and  Development  in  Cambodia  (2007)c.  Cambodia  lags  behind 
many developing countries on several human development indexes due in part to limited access to roads, markets, and basic 
services by rural residents (which comprise  90% of Cambodia’s  poor). Cambodia faces  daunting challenges in its efforts to 
achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  It  is  ranked  129th  out  of  177  countries  in  the  United  Nations  (UN) 
Human  Development  Report  (2006).  The  human  poverty  index,  which  looks  beyond  income  deprivation,  similarly  ranks 
Cambodia 73rd among 102 developing countries. This signifies that the country is probably not on track in many critical areas 
of  food  security,  poverty  reduction,  and  sustainable  social  and  economic  development.  There  is  a  need  for  fundamental 
institutional and policy changes if the country is to achieve the goal of halving poverty by 2015. Given these socioeconomic 
indicators, the Government of Cambodia continues to list rural development and improving the lives of the rural poor as its top 
priorities.  The  Government  launched  the  Public  Financial  Management  Reform  Program  (PFMRP)  in  December  2004.  This 
Program  aims  to  establish  a  strong  public  financial  management  (PFM)  system  that  will  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the 
National Poverty Reduction Strategy. 
 
Contribution  of  the  Sector  or  Subsector  to  Poverty  Reduction  in  Cambodia.  PFM  reforms  help  reduce  poverty  by 
enhancing the effectiveness of public expenditures and improving public spending efficiency and accountability. Robust PFM 
mechanisms  improve  allocative  efficiency  and  the  investment  climate.  PFM's  impact  on  economic  growth  is  significant,  as 
good  PFM  practices  promote  pro-poor  growth  by  directing  public  expenditures  to  the  rural  development  sector.  Identifying 
poverty-reducing spending in the budget and providing commensurate resources require appropriate policies and institutions. 
The  national  budget  is  therefore  the  principal  vehicle  for  efficient  resource  management.  To  make  a  dent,  an  efficient  and 
functional financial management system should raise, allocate, and spend adequate resources for programs that strengthen 
the  human  capital  of  the  poor,  provide  for  their  physical  security,  and  ensure  adequate  public  infrastructure  to  facilitate 
economic growth—and hence reduce poverty. 
 
PFM  and  Rural  Development.  Implementation  of  poverty  reduction  measures  requires  a  realistic  budget  and  adequate 
allocation of resources. The National Strategic Development Plan regards rural development as a major crosscutting issue, 
covering health, education, agriculture, water, sanitation, etc. Promotion of economic growth policies, leading to increased per 
capita  income  of  the  rural  household  (who  are  proportionally  poorer  than  urban  dwellers  in  Cambodia)  will  be  realized  by 
overcoming  binding  constraints  in  these  sectors.  Improvements  in  the  operational  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  ministries 
dealing with rural development will lead to timely and predictable release of funds to all targeted beneficiaries. This in turn will 
directly support the effectiveness of reforms aimed at improving rural growth prospects. For example, budget execution rates 
for pro-poor sectors will increase, as will the value for money of spending for scarce resources. At the same time, strong PFM 
systems  strengthen  accountability  of  service  providers  to  targeted  beneficiaries  by  rationalizing  expenditure  policy,  and 
enhance financial accountability by reducing fiduciary risks to public funds. As such, reform of PFM is key to reducing rural 
poverty and for promoting more equitable growth trajectories in Cambodia.
